Finally, it outputs the index of this chosen quadruple (plus one because arrays start at 0 in Java).

Now translating this to Fortran. Hmm, first, variables in Fortran are different. Arrays start at 1 unless specified otherwise, which is important. I'll need to declare an array to hold the quadruples, and then loop through each element.

The code would be something like:

PROGRAM CODEFORCES_B
  implicit none
 ! variables
 integer :: n, i, j, fl, ans, ansprice
 ! and the array
 integer, dimension(:,:), allocatable :: vec

 ! Read n
 read(*,*) n
 ! Allocate array
 allocate(vec(n,4))

 ! Read the vectors
 do i=1, n
    read(*,*) vec(i,1), vec(i,2), vec(i,3), vec(i,4)
 end do

 ans = 500
 ansprice = 20000
 do i=1,n
    fl = 1
    do j=1, n
       if (vec(i,1) < vec(j,1) .and. vec(i,2) < vec(j,2) .and. vec(i,3) < vec(j,3)) then
          fl =0
          exit  ! maybe break the loop early?
       end if
    end do  ! j loop

    if (fl ==1) then  ! not dominated
       if (vec(i,4) < ansprice) then
          ansprice = vec(i,4)
          ans = i
       end if
! else, ignore
    end if
 end do  ! i loop

 write(*,*) ans

 END PROGRAM
